Package org.logica.ctis.security

This simple SecurityService facilitates security for VerticalCommands, for example making sure only agents with a token that can be validated will be allowed to join the Jade Platform.

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
ConfigurableTokenProvider This interface extends the basic TokenProvider interface by adding the init() method that is invoked only once just after the TokenProvider instantiation and gives it access to Profile configurations
ConfigurableTokenValidator This interface extends the basic TokenValidator interface by adding the init() method that is invoked only once just after the TokenValidator instantiation and gives it access to Profile configurations
TokenProvider Implementors can for example follow a login procedure to retreive a token (sessionid,...) for the arguments.
TokenValidator Implementors can for example call a isValid(token) function of an external LDAP.
 

Class Summary
DummyTokenValidator  
OwnerBasedTokenProvider  
SecurityService This simple SecurityService facilitates security for VerticalCommands, for example making sure only agents with a token that can be validated will be allowed to join the Jade Platform.
 

Package org.logica.ctis.security Description

This simple SecurityService facilitates security for VerticalCommands, for example making sure only agents with a token that can be validated will be allowed to join the Jade Platform. The way it works is that at a regular container a token is retrieved and connected to an agent AID, at the Main-Container (or mediator) the token is extracted from the AID and validated. Retrieving a token and validating is a matter of implementing two very simple interfaces. Validating can be done using for example an external LDAP. The Service can contain a TokenProvider or a TokenValidator.

  • A TokenProvider provides a token for a GenericCommand, the service then connects the token to the command
  • A TokenValidator retreives a token from a GenericCommand, the service then calls validate with the token, command and objectName (AID.getName()) as arguments
Building a TokenProvider or a Validator is left to users of this security service.
  • configuration at main container
    services=org.logica.ctis.security.SecurityService(true)
    org.logica.ctis.security.SecurityService_trustedAgentNames=ams;rma;df
    org.logica.ctis.security.SecurityService_tokenvalidator=validatorClassname
  • configuration at 'client' container
    services=org.logica.ctis.security.SecurityService
    org.logica.ctis.security.SecurityService_tokenprovider=providerClassname
  • configuration at split 'client' container
    be-required-services=org.logica.ctis.security.SecurityService
    At the runtime where the 'mediator' lives: org.logica.ctis.security.SecurityService_tokenprovider=providerClassname
    or you can do validation at the mediator: org.logica.ctis.security.SecurityService_tokenvalidator=validatorClassname
    when doing validation at the mediator you probably won't use validation at the main-container

Author:
Eduard Drenth: Logica, 28-jan-2010
